metadata.title: Grading the Usefulness of Q-Scores for Coffee Scores | by Robert McKeon Aloe | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Grading the Usefulness of Q-Scores for Coffee Scores
metadata.description: In my quest to better understand Q-scores for coffee grading, I became curious how well the 10 metrics that make up a Q-score are related. I eventually found a database across multiple years…

all_paragraphs: In my quest to better understand Q-scores for coffee grading, I became curious how well the 10 metrics that make up a Q-score are related. I eventually found a database across multiple years, countries, and processes of Q-scores. Some other have looked at some initial numbers, but I did not find analysis on the fundamental question: are the sub-metrics of Q-scores independent variables? How well do coffee graders get to objective grading?

A Q-score is a culmination of 10 factors recorded during coffee cupping. I’ve summarized each metric from how I understood it from the SCA Cupping Protocol. They define how to prepare the coffee samples, how to taste, and how to score. I believe there are plenty of resources online to help understand how to do cupping with a quick search.
The final score can also lose points due to defect beans in the patch as there is a standard for how many defects are allowed.

Based these descriptions, I made a matrix of how I would assume the different metrics correlate with one another because many of them have similarities in how they are scored. They are separate metrics, but by definition, they are not completely independent variables.

In 2018, a kind soul made a script to pull a bunch of Q-scores from the Coffee Quality Institute (CQI) website to build a database of over 1300 coffee grades. I pulled this data, and I only made one addition: global region. For each country, I add the continent for that country or the general region.
I looked at the data in a few ways: box-plots, correlation, and Principle Component Analysis (PCA). Each one brings a different dimension to understanding this database.

Box plots can help one understand how the score distributions generally align, and some times, trends can come out of there. I saw some shifts, but the distributions themselves didn’t stick out to me.
Zoomed in of the same box plots:

I then looked at individual metrics, and very quickly, I found Sweetness, Clean Cup, and Uniformity are mostly scored as 10 (perfect). I am not sure what’s going on with the scores. That seems strange that more than 90% of scores for these three categories are scored at 10. This could have been a data import issue (doubtful as I have looked through some of the more recent data on the CQI website) or maybe these metrics aren’t used as commonly. All three metrics are the only quantified metrics out of the ten metrics.

I don’t have other datasets for Q-scores, and I don’t have an explanation. However, I’ll proceed with the analysis, but we should not place much weight on these. If these metrics strongly tie to the final score, it is only because they’re raising the score.

Correlation is a metric to say how similar two variables are to each other. High correlation doesn’t mean one variable causes another variable, but that both variables go up or down the same when things change. I would assume from the start that some grading variables would have a high correlation because they are looking at taste from different points in time.
Resorting helps show how well seven metrics correlate to one another.

I pulled two examples for scatter plots below. The first shows a strong correlation between Flavor and Total scores. If the Flavor is good and highly correlated to 6 other variables, then the Total score should trend. The same is true for Aftertaste and Flavor. I would expect something that tastes good to have a good aftertaste. This relationship is closer to the y=x line, but I don’t know if that is meaningful. Total score trends higher most likely because of the 3 previously discussed parameters being mostly equal to 10 as the offset seems to be about 6 in most cases between Total and Flavor (scaled by 10).
Let’s take a deeper look at the 10 variables as they correlate to the Total score but cut between region, between year, and between process:

Now we can start to see some interesting trends like why is there such a high correlation for all scores for North American beans? The same for beans from 2015? Only 8 grades are here from beans of 2018, so those high correlations aren’t useful. Why are there such low correlations between flavors and final scores in 2011?
Let’s take a dive into some years:

North America has strange scores. Everything has a high correlation to each other, which says to me that none of the metrics are particularly interesting. This brings up the question of usefulness for Q-grades or points to the graders or the countries in that region. In this case, North America is just Mexico as Central America is split into its own.
Let’s time travel in coffee tastes:

2015 is similar to North America where everything has a very high correlation to each other. It’s a curious point that demands further investigation beyond this study. Was 2015 some anomaly year for coffee? The boxplots suggest it was pretty normal.
Let’s compare processing, which is interesting for its lack of anomalies.
Processing type does have an impact on perceptions of tastes, and while the final scores have similar distributions, the Flavor for wet process has a higher correlation to the final score.

PCA is meant to transform a set of variables to a new space where the new dimensions are ordered by the amount of variability they compose of the original. A simple dataset could be reduced in the number of dimensions without loss of fidelity; in this case, each Q-score is represented by 10 dimensions, but maybe you don’t need so many to represent the total score.
Given what we know about Uniformity, Clean Cup, and Sweetness, let’s exclude those from the PCA analysis because they would not have meaningful information.

Let’s start by looking at all the data. It seems the two Principle Components (PC’s) represent 80% of all the variation in the data. While the amount of contribution for each metric seems even for the first 6 metrics, we already know all the variables are highly correlated to each other. The biggest impact being Cupper Points.

We can look across Region, Year, and Processing to see how much variation there is by how even the PC’s account for the variability in the data. North America and the year 2015 are particularly strange as we have seen from other data where 90% of all variation can be accounted in the first PC.
Zooming in, one can see for the years, 2014 and 2016 are odd as well. For processing, wet process seems to be dominated by the first PC.

We can look at the regions to help understand what variables stand out more using the PC’s. The African beans seem to have a more dominate Flavor over Acidity or Body. They have a similar trend in terms of where the variability lies like South American Beans. North American beans have all their variability in the first PC.

By year, the only strange part is that all 7 metrics are weighted similarly in the first PC. That isn’t particularly surprising considering how highly correlated the metrics are to each other for 2015.

For processing, Wet processing is dominated by the 1st PC, but for Dry processing, the first PC contains less variation. For both, the 2nd PC is dominated by Cupper Points, which is an overall metric.

When looking towards useful metrics, the data shows Uniformity, Clean Cup, and Sweetness aren’t so useful. They are genuinely the more quantifiable metrics as they are over 5 cups of the same coffee, but clearly, the variable lacks the variability required to make them useful metrics. I can only hope there was some problem in the dataset, that they aren’t really this useless.
In looking at Cupper Points, there is such a strong relationship to the total that I’m not sure as a metric it is very useful or rather it means maybe the total score isn’t very useful.

Q-grading started out to help distinguish specialty coffee from other coffee, and while I certainly think it has done that job, I don’t think the methodology is as good as it could be for distinguishing specialty coffees from each other. I base this on the above data set, and I acknowledge that maybe there’s a better data set that I don’t have access to.

I propose a new grading scale be developed for specialty coffee that goes from 0 to 100. The reality of the current scale is that typical values range from 80 to 95. Is a 92 really greatly better than a 91? I don’t know. My experience is that a 92 is better than an 85, but I hope an improved scale could cut through the ambiguity.

After posting this article, Keith Klein summarized clean cup, uniformity, and sweetness that I think are valuable to understand why they are mostly 10’s and mostly constant. I think they are still valuable to distinguish specialty coffee from non-specialty coffee, but not from distinguishing specialty coffees from each other. With his permission, here are his comments on the three metrics as well as cupper points:

“These scores relate directly to defects and are not a rating of a coffee’s inherent flavour as many people assume. You’re only supposed to to take points away from these if one of the cups has either a taint or full defect.

“Sweetness is the most lenient of these as occasionally a tainted cup will still display some sweetness and needn’t be further penalized. A coffee should only have a sweetness deduction if the cup is truly devoid of all sweetness.

“This data set comes from qualified Q graders who use these categories as intended. This shows you how strongly the Q system values defect free coffee as the penalties for defects multiply quickly. One full defect can damage a score by 10 points.

“High correlation between cupper points and total score is intended. As you come to the end of your evaluation, your cupper points are there to reward coffees that you particularly enjoyed and punish coffees that you did not enjoy.”
If you like, follow me on Twitter and YouTube where I post videos of espresso shots on different machines and espresso related stuff. You can also find me on LinkedIn.

I’m in love with my Wife, my Kids, Espresso, Data Science, tomatoes, cooking, engineering, talking, family, Paris, and Italy, not necessarily in that order.
